Seen on master: 
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=77c0694f-57ad-494f-8a66-aa3577ec92ad
@AspirinSJL , we occasionally see this on master and  it can be reproduced locally. Can you please take a look?
Sure, I'm checking it.

I'm having problem building with asan after upgrading my OS. After ignoring all the make warnings and switching to clang-5.0, I'm still having numerous `undefined reference to `__sanitizer_cov_module_init'` issues. Trying to fix this first.
Fixed the asan build issue. Checking the original problem now.
@sreecha Actually, when I am trying to reproduce this issue, I find that the test failure is overwhelmed by #12917. The flakiness is around 1/400. Maybe we need to fix that one first?

Recent failures on master:
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=7d34afc2-21ef-4a26-be86-5d20f3b81d90 (poll)
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=e2e774bd-ac0d-4922-9fa2-27e4679e82cd (poll)
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=77c0694f-57ad-494f-8a66-aa3577ec92ad (poll)
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=b067b883-94af-4ec4-ad5f-fe92d766ab2d (epollex)
https://sponge.corp.google.com/invocation?id=ec0f05db-89f5-4b51-b1cf-222f6d8174ec (epollex)

There seems to be two distinct failures:
First one is `sync.cc:93: void gpr_ref_non_zero(gpr_refcount *): Assertion 'prior > 0' failed.`:
```
D0302 21:26:27.169451562   30611 end2end_test.cc:217]        TestScenario{use_proxy=true, inproc=false, credentials='INSECURE_CREDENTIALS'}
D0302 21:26:27.169780577   30611 ev_posix.cc:142]            Using polling engine: poll
D0302 21:26:27.169837144   30611 dns_resolver.cc:331]        Using native dns resolver
D0302 21:26:27.172992463   30611 ev_posix.cc:142]            Using polling engine: poll
D0302 21:26:27.173081934   30611 dns_resolver.cc:331]        Using native dns resolver
I0302 21:26:27.173439099   30611 server_builder.cc:269]      Synchronous server. Num CQs: 4, Min pollers: 1, Max Pollers: 2, CQ timeout (msec): 10
I0302 21:26:27.179491964   30611 server_builder.cc:269]      Synchronous server. Num CQs: 4, Min pollers: 1, Max Pollers: 2, CQ timeout (msec): 10
I0302 21:26:27.182784893   30611 subchannel.cc:607]          New connected subchannel at 0x603000023bf0 for subchannel 0x61600008d980
end2end_test: src/core/lib/gpr/sync.cc:93: void gpr_ref_non_zero(gpr_refcount *): Assertion `prior > 0' failed.
```

and the other one is a memory leak (or a heap-use-after-free).

When trying to reproduce locally, all I'm getting is 
```
I0309 10:15:46.813531448  142565 subchannel.cc:607]          New connected subchannel at 0x60300006d9c0 for subchannel 0x61600005e280
test/cpp/end2end/end2end_test.cc:1300: Failure
      Expected: StatusCode::DEADLINE_EXCEEDED
      Which is: 4
To be equal to: s.error_code()
      Which is: 0
```
not sure if that's because  the 40ms server sleep in the test case is not sufficient or if there's some newly introduce change has made the test more prone to failure.
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/59ea0ae3ebcca0aef5a15c5aa5b4d27b7f3fc9c4/test/cpp/end2end/end2end_test.cc#L1293

Update:
after increasing the `set_server_sleep_us` I was able to reproduce locally the `sync.cc:93: void gpr_ref_non_zero(gpr_refcount *): Assertion 'prior > 0' failed.` issue.

The leaks seem to be caused by failure to cleanly shutdown tcp-server-connection (in which case there's an obvious leak). I checked and some of the sponge logs and they are also reporting this problem.

`D0306 06:13:31.618856486    5647 iomgr.cc:127]               Failed to free 1 iomgr objects before shutdown deadline: memory leaks are likely
D0306 06:13:31.618919351    5647 iomgr.cc:75]                LEAKED OBJECT: tcp-server-connection:ipv4:127.0.0.1:53600 fd=14 0x61100004ffa8`

(which could also explain why we aren't seeing failures for opt and dbg - although I thought that for our tests we are setting a flag that whenever we fail to free iomgr objects on time, that results in assertion error precisely because we want to be able to catch these error).

I was poking into this a few nights ago. As the logs above show, the crash comes from this line:

https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/59ea0ae3ebcca0aef5a15c5aa5b4d27b7f3fc9c4/src/core/lib/surface/call.cc#L1230

So it looks like some race condition in which the server thinks it has child calls but doesn't.

@ncteisen I think there is a child call (there's a proxy in place).  https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/59ea0ae3ebcca0aef5a15c5aa5b4d27b7f3fc9c4/test/cpp/end2end/end2end_test.cc#L177  (please doublecheck, you know the code better than I do)

But I agree that there's some kind of race - we're probably hitting some edge case in the parent - child propagation.

the last line ` (null) 0x7f79a000d9d0:(nil)   REF 0->1 propagate_cancel`   is pretty odd.   It looks like the refcount object wasn't yet initialized or it was already destroyed. See the end of this comment for explanation why I think the refcount is not fully initialized yet.

Ok, I'm now 99% sure that the stream_refcount is getting initialized by another thread concurrently with the refcount being updated.

Thread 160601  calls  grpc_stream_ref_init  but thread 160560 is accessing it before it's fully populated.
```
D0309 18:18:22.534668087  160601 transport.cc:43]            CLIENT_CHANNEL 0x5629f305f500:0x5629f305f4a0   REF 1->2 call

end2end_test: src/core/lib/gpr/sync.cc:93: void gpr_ref_non_zero(gpr_refcount*): Assertion `prior > 0' failed.
```

Good point about the proxy... definitely will be child call.

The refcount modification is protected by `child_list_mu`. I bet the initialization code should be taking that lock, but is not

I think the rootcause is in `grpc_call_create`.

1. While the new call is being initialized, if there's a parent call, the call is published in the parent's call child list (that's part is protected child_list_mu)
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/59ea0ae3ebcca0aef5a15c5aa5b4d27b7f3fc9c4/src/core/lib/surface/call.cc#L381

2. But the call published is actually not fully initialized yet  - the next thing that's done is  actually initializing the call's  refcount  (which boils down to grpc_stream_ref_init).
https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/59ea0ae3ebcca0aef5a15c5aa5b4d27b7f3fc9c4/src/core/lib/surface/call.cc#L447 

3. Another thread takes hold of the parent's child list (which contained pointer to the ininitialized call) and if the timing is right and the parent call is just finalizing, it also accesses  the new call's  refcount - which is not fully initialized yet (there's a race).
